intro: Calycobolus bampsianus, commonly known as the Bampsian calycobolus, is a rare flowering plant native to specific regions of South America. It belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes hibiscus and cotton plants. The plant is characterized by its striking, showy flowers that typically bloom in shades of red and purple. Its leaves are palmate, with five to seven lobes, and the plant prefers well-drained, sandy soils. Due to habitat loss, it is considered endangered and is protected in several conservation programs.
